title: Letters: Trump turns military raid into circus
text:
Non-essential services should feel tax pain

Does a regressive tax on the essentials of life really deserve to be called tax reform? Is this the best we can do?

If our current tax system reduces the incentives to work, save, hire and invest, then shifting that burden by expanding the GST to cover fresh food, health and childcare will likewise reduce the incentives to purchase those products and services. This is not an outcome we should be aiming for.

When a company like Netflix can pay just 0.06 per cent tax on local earnings, there are clearly some non-essential services that can shoulder more of the tax burden.

Mitchell Browne

Blaxland, NSW

Heavy hand needed for recalcitrant institutions

Scott Morrison speaks gravely to institutions that have not yet accepted responsibility for providing restitution, reconciliation and compensation to their victims of abuse, and asks them to ‘‘Do the right thing; the honourable thing’’.

That’s not good enough, Prime Minister. Remove their tax-exempt status and other privileges until they do comply and meet their obligations.

It’s clear from their actions that only a financial ‘stick’ will carry any weight. Any ‘carrots’, whether about honour, fairness or responsibility, clearly do not work – we have ample evidence of that.

Philip Carman

West Perth, WA

Froth and bubble for introverted Canberra

So much for the Canberra bubble. Prime Minister Scott Morrison has created his own bubble, in which he and the government make policy and decisions on the basis of a narrow, partisan view of the national interest and in isolation from experts and other sources of diverse thinking.

Clearly the PM is master of his own bubble. What is worrying is that he is now trying to control others outside the bubble.

The controlling rhetoric and actions of those inside the bubble include intimidation and punishment of dissenters in the media and individual whistleblowers, reducing the public service to ‘yes men’, suggesting the business sector stick to its knitting and not attend to ‘social issues’, accusing the media of misrepresentation, blaming ‘negative globalism’ for bad raps about government policies and the peddling of allegedly fraudulent documents.

The Morrison bubble has obvious similarities with the house of Trump and Australians should not miss the point that the bubble has a growing authoritarian nature.

Meanwhile, the opposition is treading water and appears to have become meek in the face of the Morrison bubble.

Advertisement

Mark Beavis

Mount Evelyn, Vic

Let the private sector worry about new buses

The NSW Minister for Transport wants to replace all 8000 of Sydney’s diesel buses with electric ones. This would come at a vast cost to the state, in a process that will take umpteen years and cause at least as much disruption as the light rail has done.

Surely a decision on such an ordeal is best left to private industry? After all, the NSW government wants to privatise Sydney’s buses. It would be nothing but stupid for it to invest huge amounts of money that could be better used for schools, hospitals, roads and so on, just so that the expensive new buses could then be sold for private operators.

Somebody, please explain.

Grant Agnew

Coopers Plains, Qld

Renewables not adding to the cost of energy

The article ‘‘Basslink constraints add to grid concerns’’ (October 28) is misleading in two important areas. It implies renewables are adding to the price of energy whereas this is clearly not the case. Without this new supply, energy prices would be much higher due the closure of the old and unsafe Hazelwood site and the increasingly unreliable remaining coal-powered stations.

Also the journalist fails to acknowledge that South Australian power prices have plummeted to now be marginally below Victorian power prices and closing in on NSW prices. What is this telling us?

Rory Ross

Glen Iris, Vic

WeWork not really working as planned

Robert Harley’s ‘‘Why the money is pouring into proptech’’ (October 24) implies that WeWork is a proptech business. You stand corrected – there’s no proptech – just plain rent arbitrage and hot air.

Apparently WeDoesn’tWork.

Craig Wright

Elwood, Vic
